--------------------------------------------------------------------
                         Complete Solution
--------------------------------------------------------------------

1. Problem Analysis
   • A pendulum bob of mass m = 0.1 M hangs from a carriage (mass M) that can move only along the x–direction.  
   • The carriage is suddenly pulled by a constant horizontal force F ( → uniform acceleration a ).  
   • The whole experiment takes place at the North Pole, so the Earth–fixed frame is rotating with angular velocity  
     Ω⃗  = Ω ẑ (ẑ is vertically upward).  
   • We must find the small-angle horizontal displacement x(t) of the bob with respect to the accelerating carriage, taking the Coriolis force into account, and with the initial conditions  
     x(0)=0 , ẋ(0)=0 .

   Useful data supplied  
        g/l = ω₀² ,  ω₀² = 10 Ω² ,  m = 0.1 M .

2. Approach
   • Work in the (non-inertial) frame of the carriage that is attached to the rotating Earth.  
   • Write Newton’s 2nd law including: real forces (gravity, tension) and fictitious forces (Coriolis + translational).  
   • Linearise for small angles (θ ≃ x/l , y/l).  
   • Obtain coupled linear ODE’s for the horizontal coordinates x(t), y(t).  
   • Combine them with a complex variable z = x + i y, solve the single complex ODE, impose the initial
     conditions, and finally take the real part to obtain x(t).  

3. Solution Steps
---------------------------------------------------------------
3.1  Carriage acceleration  
     The total mass that the force F must accelerate is M+m, so  

              a = F/(M+m) .                              (1)

     This produces a translational inertial (pseudo-)force −m a x̂ on the bob in the carriage frame.

---------------------------------------------------------------
3.2  Forces in the carriage frame (Earth-fixed, rotating)  
     • Gravity           :  −mg ẑ  
     • Tension           :   T along the string  
     • Coriolis          :  −2 m Ω⃗ × v⃗    (v⃗ is the bob’s velocity w.r.t. Earth)  
     • Translational     :  −m a x̂  
     • Centrifugal       :  −m Ω⃗ × (Ω⃗ × r⃗ )  (vanishes at the pole because Ω⃗ ∥ ẑ)  

---------------------------------------------------------------
3.3  Linearised equations of motion  
     Let (x,y) be the small horizontal displacements; θₓ ≃ x/l , θᵧ ≃ y/l.  
     To first order, the vertical balance gives T ≃ mg, so   
                       (T/l) x ≃ m (g/l) x = m ω₀² x ,
                       (T/l) y ≃ m (g/l) y = m ω₀² y .

     Writing Newton’s law in x and y,

     x–direction :  m ẍ = −m ω₀² x  − m a  + 2 m Ω ẏ ,        (2a)  
     y–direction :  m ÿ = −m ω₀² y  − 2 m Ω ẋ .                (2b)

     Divide by m:

              ẍ + ω₀² x − 2 Ω ẏ = −a ,                       (3a)  
              ÿ + ω₀² y + 2 Ω ẋ = 0 .                         (3b)

---------------------------------------------------------------
3.4  Single complex differential equation  
     Introduce   z(t) ≡ x(t) + i y(t).  
     Using (3a,b) one finds

              z̈ + 2 i Ω ż + ω₀² z = −a .                     (4)

---------------------------------------------------------------
3.5  Remove the constant forcing  
     A constant particular solution is z_p = −a/ω₀².  
     Put    z = u − a/ω₀² ,  then u satisfies the homogeneous equation

              ü + 2 i Ω u̇ + ω₀² u = 0 .                      (5)

---------------------------------------------------------------
3.6  Foucault transformation  
     Write  u(t) = v(t) e^{−i Ω t}.  
     Substituting into (5) gives a simple harmonic equation for v(t):

              v̈ + (ω₀² + Ω²) v = 0 .                          (6)

     Define the natural “mixed” frequency

              ω₁ ≡ √(ω₀² + Ω²) = √(10 Ω² + Ω²) = √11 Ω.       (7)

     Hence

              v(t) = A cos(ω₁ t) + B sin(ω₁ t).               (8)

---------------------------------------------------------------
3.7  Apply the initial conditions  
     z(0) = x(0) + i y(0) = 0  ⇒  u(0)= a/ω₀² .  
     ż(0) = 0  ⇒  u̇(0) = 0.

     • From (8): v(0)=A,  v̇(0)=B ω₁.  
     • Because u = v e^{−i Ω t},  u(0)=v(0)=A = a/ω₀² .  
     • u̇(0)= −i Ω A + B ω₁ = 0  ⇒  B = i (Ω/ω₁) A.

     Therefore

              u(t)=A e^{−i Ω t}\big[\,cos(ω₁ t)+i (Ω/ω₁) sin(ω₁ t)\big],
              A = a/ω₀².                                       (9)

---------------------------------------------------------------
3.8  Extract x(t) = Re{z(t)}  
     z = u − a/ω₀², so

     x(t)= Re{u(t)} − a/ω₀²
         = (a/ω₀²) [ cos(Ω t) cos(ω₁ t) + (Ω/ω₁) sin(Ω t) sin(ω₁ t) ] − a/ω₀²
         = − (a/ω₀²) \Big\{ 1 − cos(Ω t) cos(ω₁ t) − (Ω/ω₁) sin(Ω t) sin(ω₁ t) \Big\}.        (10)

---------------------------------------------------------------
3.9  Insert a, numerical ratios, and m = 0.1 M  
     • a = F/(M+m) = F/(1.1 M).  
     • ω₀² = 10 Ω² ,  ω₁ = √11 Ω.

     Hence

       x(t)= −\frac{F}{(1.1 M)\, 10 Ω²}
              \Big\{ 1 − \cos(Ω t)\cos(\sqrt{11}\,Ω t)
                       − \frac{1}{\sqrt{11}}\sin(Ω t)\sin(\sqrt{11}\,Ω t) \Big\}.        (11)

     Multiplying numerator and denominator by 10 gives the particularly neat form

       x(t)= -\frac{F}{11 M Ω^{2}}
              \Big\{ 1 - \cos(Ω t)\cos(\sqrt{11}\,Ω t)
                       -\frac{1}{\sqrt{11}} \sin(Ω t)\sin(\sqrt{11}\,Ω t) \Big\}.          (12)

     One may check quickly:
     • t→0 : x ≃ −½ a t² (as expected for a suddenly accelerated frame).  
     • No exponential factor appears; the amplitude stays constant, the plane of oscillation precesses at rate Ω (Foucault effect).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,%
x(t)= -\frac{F}{11 M \,\Omega^{2}}
        \left[1-\cos\!\bigl(\Omega t\bigr)\cos\!\bigl(\sqrt{11}\,\Omega t\bigr)
              -\frac{1}{\sqrt{11}}\;\sin\!\bigl(\Omega t\bigr)\sin\!\bigl(\sqrt{11}\,\Omega t\bigr)
        \right]\,} 
\]

questions:
The problem discusses a stick figure model. The stick figure's head is a uniform sphere with a radius of $r$ and a mass of $m$, while the rest of the body consists of uniform rods with negligible thickness and a mass per unit length of $\lambda$. All parts are connected by hinges. Specifically, the torso and both arms have a length of $l$, while the legs have a length of $1.2l$. $\theta$ represents the angle between the arms and the torso, and $\varphi$ represents the angle between the legs and the extended torso line (not an obtuse angle). The stick figure is composed of a head, a torso, two arms, and two legs. Initially, the stick figure is in a state where $\theta=\textstyle{\frac{\pi}{2}}$ and $\varphi={\frac{\pi}{4}}$. The head has a mass of $m=0.6\lambda l$, with the result expressed in terms of $\lambda$. 

The stick figure is a simulation of a real biological body, so if necessary, the connections between the torso and the arms/legs, in addition to providing interaction forces, can also exert a couple (i.e., a torque), even if there is no interaction force between them. This net torque is independent of the choice of reference point. In the following discussion, this will be referred to simply as a "couple."

During a certain free-fall motion, the stick figure, overwhelmed with panic, forgets to bring its legs together and swings its arms and torso with an amplitude of $\theta_{0}$ (small angle) and an angular frequency of $\omega$. As a result, its legs passively oscillate near $\varphi={\frac{\pi}{4}}$. Find the amplitude of resonance for the legs (seek the steady-state solution starting from the initial position). Assume that the stick figure can actively generate a couple for the arms but not for the legs.

(1) The forces are already marked on the diagram. List Newton's laws and rotational equations, assuming the displacement of the driven object is $\pmb{x}$, positive upwards.

Vertical direction of the leg

$$
T_{3}=1.2\lambda l\times\left(0.6l\times{\frac{d^{2}}{d t^{2}}}\left({\mathrm{cos}}\varphi\right)-{\ddot{x}}\right)
$$

$$
T_{1}=\lambda l\left(\ddot{x}-0.5l\times\frac{d^{2}}{d t^{2}}\left(\mathrm{cos}\theta\right)\right)
$$

Vertical direction of the torso (head)

$$
2\left(T_{3}-T_{1}\right)=(m+\lambda l)\ddot{x}
$$

Horizontal direction of the leg

$$
-T_{4}=1.2\lambda l\times0.6l\times\frac{d^{2}}{d t^{2}}\left(\mathrm{sin}\varphi\right)
$$

Horizontal direction of the arm

$$
-T_{2}=\lambda l\times0.5l\times{\frac{d^{2}}{d t^{2}}}\left(\mathrm{sin}\theta\right)

Angular momentum theorem for the leg

$$
T_{3}\times0.6l\mathrm{sin}\varphi+T_{4}\times0.6l\mathrm{cos}\varphi-M=\frac{1}{12}\times1.2\lambda l\times(1.2l)^{2}\ddot{\varphi}
$$

Angular momentum theorem for the arm

$$
T_{2}\times0.5l\mathrm{cos}\theta-T_{1}\times0.5l\mathrm{sin}\theta=\frac{1}{12}\times\lambda l\times l^{2}\ddot{\theta}

Substitute in, we have

By combining the previous equations, we get

Therefore,

$$
\begin{array}{c}{{A(\theta)=\displaystyle\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{12}\mathrm{sin}^{2}\theta}}\ {{{}}}\ {{B(\theta)=-\displaystyle\frac{1}{12}\mathrm{sin}\theta\mathrm{cos}\theta}}\ {{{}}}\ {{C(\theta)=\displaystyle\frac{3}{25}\omega^{2}\mathrm{sin}\theta}}\end{array}

Substituting back into the previous angular momentum theorem, we have

$$
\begin{array}{r l r}{M=\frac{9}{25}\mathrm{sin}\varphi\lambda l^{3}\left(\frac{12}{25}\mathrm{cos}\varphi\omega^{2}+\frac{1}{3}\mathrm{cos}\theta\dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{3}\mathrm{sin}\theta\ddot{\theta}\right)}&{{}=\frac{12}{25}\frac{\mathrm{sin}\varphi}{\mathrm{sin}\theta}\ddot{\theta}}\end{array}

$$

Solution Outline

1. Problem Analysis  
   The figure’s legs are free (they cannot be actuated), whereas from the hip upward (torso + head + two arms) the figure can exert an internal couple and imposes the small harmonic motion  
   θ(t)=θ₀cos ωt   (θ₀≪1).  
   This motion produces, through the hip hinge, a time–periodic couple on the legs.  
   Each leg therefore behaves as a driven physical pendulum:

              I_L φ¨+Κ φ = τ̂ cos ωt                        (1)

   with I_L the total moment of inertia of the two legs about the hip, Κ the small–angle gravitational
   torsional constant, and τ̂ the amplitude of the couple delivered by the upper part of the body.  
   The required steady (forced) oscillation amplitude φ̂ is asked for, i.e. the “resonance amplitude of the legs”.

2. Dynamical Parameters  

   2.1 Legs  
   Length of one leg           L_L = 1.2 l  
   Mass of one leg             m_L = λL_L = 1.2 λ l  

   Moment of inertia of one uniform rod about one end  
              I_L(1) = ⅓ m_L L_L² = ⅓(1.2 λ l)(1.2 l)²
                       = 0.576 λ l³

   For the two identical legs                                          

              I_L  = 2I_L(1) = 1.152 λ l³                                    (2)

   Small–angle gravitational restoring torque of one leg

              τ_g(1)= m_Lg(L_L/2) φ

   so that for two legs

              Κ  = 2m_Lg(L_L/2)
                 = 2(1.2 λ l)g(0.6 l)
                 = 1.44 λ l²g                                           (3)

   Natural (undriven) angular frequency of the legs

              ω₀² = Κ/I_L = (1.44 λ l²g)/(1.152 λ l³)
                    = 1.25 g/l                                         (4)

              ω₀ = √(5g/4l)

   2.2 Upper part of the body (driver)  
   Masses  
      Torso (uniform rod, length l):      m_T = λ l  
      Two arms (each length l):           m_A = 2λ l  
      Head (uniform sphere):              m_H = 0.6 λ l  

      M_U = m_T+m_A+m_H = 3.6 λ l                         (5)

   Distance of their common centre of mass from the hip  

              R_U = [m_T(l/2) + m_H(l+r) + m_A l] / M_U
                   = (3.1 l + 0.6 r)/3.6                       (6)

   Moment of inertia of the upper part about the hip  

      • Torso (rod, pivot at one end)          I_T = ⅓ m_T l² = 0.333 λ l³  
      • Head (parallel–axis theorem)           I_H = m_H[(l+r)² + ⅖r²]  
      • Each arm (COM at (l, ±l/2); axis ⟂ plane)

                 I_A(1)= m_A/2 [l²+ (l/2)²] + (1/12)m_A/2 l²
                       = 1.333 λ l³

        For two arms                                    I_A = 2I_A(1)=2.667 λ l³

      Hence                                                   

              I_U = I_T + I_H + I_A                   (7)

   (The answer may be left with I_H and thus r explicit.)

3. Couple acting on the legs  

   The figure purposefully enforces θ(t)=θ₀cos ωt.  
   The couple that must be supplied to the upper part is

              τ_active(t)= I_U θ¨ + M_UgR_U θ
                         = θ₀(I_Uω² – M_UgR_U)cos ωt         (8)

   By Newton’s third law the reaction on the legs is opposite:

              τ̂ = |I_Uω² – M_UgR_U| θ₀                    (9)

4. Forced-oscillation equation for the legs  

              I_L φ¨ + Κ φ = τ̂ cos ωt                     (10)

   Its steady periodic solution is

              φ(t)= φ̂ cos(ωt – δ)  with  

              φ̂ = τ̂ / √[(Κ – I_Lω²)²]                   (11)
                  = τ̂ / |I_L(ω₀² – ω²)|                  (12)

   Inserting (2), (3) and (9):

              φ̂ = θ₀
                    |I_Uω² – M_UgR_U|
                    /[ I_L|ω₀² – ω²| ]                    (13)

5. Resonance amplitude  

   The amplitude becomes largest when the driving frequency approaches the natural
   frequency of the legs (ω ≈ ω₀).  Formally, in the absence of damping,

              ω → ω₀  ⇒  |ω₀² – ω²| → 0  ⇒  φ̂ → ∞.

   In practice a small damping Γ would bound the response; replacing |ω₀²–ω²|
   by √[(ω₀²–ω²)²+4Γ²ω²] one would obtain the finite resonant peak

              φ̂_res = θ₀
                         |I_Uω₀² – M_UgR_U|
                         /(2I_LΓω₀).                      (14)

   Keeping to the ideal‐undamped statement of the problem, the steady-state amplitude is therefore given by (13).

### Final Answer  

The passive motion of the two legs is that of a driven physical pendulum.  
With  
 I_L = 1.152 λ l³,  Κ = 1.44 λ l²g  ⇒ ω₀ = √(5g/4l)  

and with the upper-body parameters  
 M_U = 3.6 λ l,  R_U = (3.1 l+0.6 r)/3.6,  I_U as written in (7),

the steady-state oscillation amplitude of the legs is  

\[ \boxed{ \displaystyle
\phi_{\text{amp}}( \omega)=
\theta_{0}\;
\frac{\bigl|\,I_{U}\,\omega^{2}-M_{U}g\,R_{U}\bigr|}
      {\,I_{L}\,\bigl|\,\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\bigr|}\,,
\qquad
\omega_{0}^{2}=1.25\,\frac{g}{l}\; } \]

In the ideal undamped case this expression diverges as ω→ω₀, i.e. the legs resonate when the driving frequency equals their natural frequency √(5g/4l).

questions: In this problem, we study a simple \"gas-fueled rocket.\" The main body of the rocket is a plastic bottle, which can take off after adding a certain amount of fuel gas and igniting it. It is known that the external atmospheric pressure is $P_{0}$, and the initial pressure of the gas in the bottle is $P_{0}$, with a temperature of $T_{0}$. The proportion of the molar amount of fuel gas is $\alpha$, and the rest is air. Alcohol is chosen as the fuel, with the reaction equation in air as: $C_{2}H_{5}OH(g) + 3O_{2}(g) \rightarrow 3H_{2}O(g) + 2CO_{2}(g)$. Assume that the air contains only $N_{2}$ and $O_{2}$, all gases are considered as ideal gases, and none of the vibrational degrees of freedom are excited. It is known that under conditions of pressure $P_{0}$ and temperature $T_{0}$, the reaction heat is $-\lambda$ (enthalpy change for $1\mathrm{mol}$ of ethanol reacting under isothermal and isobaric conditions). Ignore heat loss, assume the reaction is complete, and that there is air remaining, with the gas volume remaining constant throughout. Find the pressure $P_{1}$ of the gas inside the bottle after the gas has completely reacted upon ignition.
solutions: Let the initial moles of air be $n_{0}$, and the moles of alcohol be  $$ n_{x}=\frac{\alpha n_{0}}{1-\alpha} $$ The ideal gas equation of state is $$ {P_{0}V_{0}=\left(n_{x}+n_{0}\right)R T_{0}} \\ {P_{0}V_{1}=\left(2n_{x}+n_{0}\right)R T_{0}} $$ According to the definition of enthalpy change, we have $$ \Delta{{H}_{0}}=\Delta{{U}_{0}}+\Delta\left(P V\right)=\Delta{{U}_{0}}+{{P}_{0}}\left({{V}_{1}}-{{V}_{0}}\right) $$ It follows that $$ \Delta U_{0}=-n_{x}\lambda-n_{x}RT_{0} $$ Since heat loss is neglected and no gas escapes from the bottle, the reaction is adiabatic and the volume does not change, giving us $$ \Delta U=\Delta U_{\mathrm{0}}+\Big[\frac{5}{2}R\cdot\big(n_{0}-n_{x}\big)+3R\cdot 3n_{x}\Big]\big(T_{1}-T_{0}\big)=0 $$ We obtain $$ T_{1}=T_{0}+\frac{2n_{x}\left(\lambda+R T_{0}\right)}{R\left(5n_{0}+13n_{x}\right)}=T_{0}+\frac{2\alpha\left(\lambda+R T_{0}\right)}{R\left(5+8\alpha\right)} $$ The ideal gas equation of state is $$ {P_{0}V_{0}=\left(n_{x}+n_{0}\right)R T_{0}} \\ {P_{1}V_{0}=\left(2n_{x}+n_{0}\right)R T_{1}} $$ We find $$ P_{1}=P_{0}\frac{(1+\alpha)(5+10\alpha+2\alpha(\frac{\lambda}{R T_{0}}))}{5+8\alpha} $$

Solution Outline  

1. Problem Analysis  
   • A mixture of ethanol vapour (molar proportion α) and air (79 % N₂   +  21 % O₂) is at p = P₀ and T = T₀.  
   • Combustion takes place at constant volume.  
   • All gases are ideal; only translational and rotational degrees of freedom are active.  
   • The isobaric‐isothermal molar enthalpy of reaction of ethanol in air is –λ.  
   • We must find the final pressure P₁ after the reaction heat has raised the temperature of the (now changed) gas mixture.

2. Approach in words  
   (a) Stoichiometry fixes how many moles of each species are present after ignition.  
   (b) At constant volume the released internal energy raises the temperature:  
        Q = –ΔU = C_V,tot (T_f–T₀).  
   (c) P₁ then follows from the ideal–gas law  
        P₁/P₀ = (n_f/n₀)(T_f/T₀).  
   (d) Two regimes occur: fuel-lean/stoichiometric (enough O₂) and fuel-rich (O₂ limiting).

3. Detailed Solution  

   3.1   Basic relations  

        Reaction:     C₂H₅OH(g) + 3 O₂(g) → 3 H₂O(g) + 2 CO₂(g)    (1)

        At T₀, p = P₀      ΔH_rxn = –λ  (per mol ethanol)  
        Δn ≡ mol(products) – mol(reactants) = 5 – 4 = 1  

        ΔU_rxn = ΔH_rxn – ΔnRT₀ = –λ – RT₀  (2)

        |ΔU_rxn| = λ + RT₀ is the energy set free per mol ethanol under constant-V conditions.

        Initial total moles:     n₀ = P₀V/RT₀  

        Initial moles of each gas  
        Ethanol             :  αn₀  
        O₂                  :  0.21(1–α)n₀  
        N₂                  :  0.79(1–α)n₀                                            (3)

   3.2   Stoichiometric limit for complete combustion  

        Ethanol needs 3 mol O₂ per mol (see Eq. 1).  
        O₂ needed  = 3αn₀  
        O₂ supplied = 0.21(1–α)n₀  

        Complete combustion possible if        3α ≤ 0.21(1–α)  
        ⇒ α ≤ α_s , with α_s = 0.21 / (3 + 0.21) ≃ 6.54 % ≃ 0.065  (4)

        We therefore treat

        Regime I  (fuel-lean or stoichiometric)  : 0 ≤ α ≤ α_s  
        Regime II (fuel-rich, O₂ limiting)       : α ≥ α_s

   3.3   Degrees of freedom and C_V values (vibrations neglected)  

        Diatomic (N₂ , O₂)  f = 5 ⇒ C_V = 5/2 R  
        Linear triatomic (CO₂) f = 5 ⇒ C_V = 5/2 R  
        Non-linear triatomic (H₂O) and ethanol f = 6 ⇒ C_V = 3 R

   3.4   REGIME I ( 0 ≤ α ≤ α_s )

        Final mole numbers (using (1))  
        H₂O : 3αn₀   CO₂ : 2αn₀  
        O₂  : [0.21(1–α) – 3α] n₀ = (0.21 – 3.21α) n₀  
        N₂  : 0.79(1–α)n₀                                             (5)

        Total moles           n_f = (α + 1) n₀  (6)

        Total constant-volume heat capacity  

        C_V,tot = R n₀( 2.5 + 4α )  (7)  
        (algebra: see coefficient sum below)

        Energy balance  

        αn₀(λ + RT₀) = C_V,tot (T_f – T₀)  
        ⇒ T_f = T₀ [ 1 + α(λ/RT₀ + 1)/(2.5 + 4α) ] ≡ T₀ τ₁  (8)

        τ₁(α) = 1 + α(Λ+1)/(2.5 + 4α)  with Λ ≡ λ/(RT₀)

        Pressure ratio  

        P₁/P₀ = (n_f/n₀)(T_f/T₀) = (1 + α) τ₁(α)             (9)

   3.5   REGIME II ( α ≥ α_s )

        Only α_s n₀ mol of ethanol can burn; the remaining α_u = α – α_s is inert.

        Products and residual gases  

        H₂O : 3α_s n₀   CO₂ : 2α_s n₀  
        N₂  : 0.79(1–α)n₀  (unaffected)  
        Unburned C₂H₅OH : α_u n₀                                      (10)

        Total moles  

        n_f = n₀ [ 0.79 + 0.21α + 4α_s ]                            (11)

        Total C_V  

        C_V,tot = R n₀ [ 1.975 – 1.975α + 11α_s + 3α ]  
                 = R n₀ [ 1.975 + 11α_s + 1.025α ] ≡ R n₀ c′(α)  (12)

        Energy released (only what burns)  

        Q = α_s n₀ (λ + RT₀)

        Energy balance  

        α_s(λ + RT₀) = R n₀ c′(α) (T_f – T₀)

        ⇒ T_f = T₀ [ 1 + α_s(λ/RT₀ + 1)/c′(α) ] ≡ T₀ τ₂(α)  (13)

        Pressure ratio  

        P₁/P₀ = (n_f/n₀) τ₂(α) = [0.79 + 0.21α + 4α_s] τ₂(α)      (14)

4. Result collected  

Let  

Λ = λ /(RT₀),  α_s = 0.21/(3+0.21) ≈ 0.0654  

Then

A)  Fuel-lean or stoichiometric mixture  ( 0 ≤ α ≤ α_s )  

  P₁ = P₀ (1 + α) [ 1 + α(Λ + 1)/(2.5 + 4α) ]                   (15)

B)  Fuel-rich mixture  ( α ≥ α_s )  

  c′(α) = 1.975 + 11α_s + 1.025α  

  P₁ = P₀ [0.79 + 0.21α + 4α_s] [ 1 + α_s(Λ + 1)/c′(α) ]        (16)

Both expressions are continuous at α = α_s and give the final pressure in terms of the initial state (P₀, T₀), the molar ethanol fraction α and the tabulated enthalpy λ.

### Final Answer  
\[
\boxed{
\begin{cases}
\displaystyle
P_{1}=P_{0}\,(1+\alpha)\!\left[\,1+\dfrac{\alpha\left( \dfrac{\lambda}{R\,T_{0}}+1\right)}{\,\dfrac52+4\alpha}\right], & 0\le \alpha\le \alpha_{s},\\[1.2em]
\displaystyle
P_{1}=P_{0}\,\bigl(0.79+0.21\alpha+4\alpha_{s}\bigr)\!\left[\,1+\dfrac{\alpha_{s}\left( \dfrac{\lambda}{R\,T_{0}}+1\right)}{\,1.975+11\alpha_{s}+1.025\alpha}\right], & \alpha\ge \alpha_{s},
\end{cases}
\quad\alpha_{s}= \frac{0.21}{3+0.21}\simeq 0.0654
}
\]

questions: A fox is escaping along a straight line $AB$ at a constant speed $v_{1}$. A hound is pursuing it at a constant speed $v_{2}$, always aimed at the fox. At a certain moment, the fox is at $F$ and the hound is at $D$. $FD \bot AB$ and $FD = L$. Find the magnitude of the hound's acceleration at this moment.
solutions:
To solve $\textcircled{1}$, the hunting dog performs uniform circular motion. Thus, the tangential acceleration is zero, while the normal acceleration changes. Assume that during a very short period of time $\mathrm{d}t$ after the given moment, the curvature radius of the trajectory of the hunting dog is $\rho,$ then the normal acceleration is  

$$
a_{n}={\frac{v_{2}^{2}}{\rho}}.
$$

During the time interval $\mathrm{d}t$, the fox and the hunting dog respectively reach positions $F^{\prime}$ and $D^{\prime}$ (see Figure 1.7(a) in the problem). The angle turned by the hunting dog's direction of motion is  

$$
\alpha={\frac{\widehat{D D^{\prime}}}{\rho}}={\frac{v_{2}\mathrm{d}t}{\rho}}.
$$

However, the distance traveled by the fox is  

$$
\begin{array}{r}{\overline{{F F^{\prime}}}=v_{1}\mathrm{d}t\approx L\tan\alpha\approx\alpha L,}\end{array}
$$

which implies  

$$
\alpha={\frac{v_{1}\mathrm{d}t}{L}}.
$$

Thus,  

$$
\frac{\upsilon_{2}\mathrm{d}t}{\rho}=\frac{\upsilon_{1}\mathrm{d}t}{L},
$$

and from this, the curvature radius can be obtained as  

$$
\rho=\frac{L v_{2}}{v_{1}}.
$$

Therefore, the magnitude of the acceleration is  

$$
a_{n}={\frac{v_{2}^{2}}{\rho}}={\frac{v_{1}v_{2}}{L}}.
$$

It should be noted that the acceleration obtained this way corresponds only to the specific moment mentioned in the problem, not to the acceleration at any arbitrary position during the chasing process.
improved_solutions:
1. Problem Analysis  
The fox (speed v₁) runs straight along line AB.  
The hound (speed v₂, magnitude constant) always heads directly toward the fox, so its velocity direction continually changes.  
At the instant considered the fox is at point F, the hound at point D, with FD ⟂ AB and FD = L.  
Because only the direction of the hound’s velocity changes, its acceleration is purely “centripetal.”  
We must find the magnitude a of this acceleration at that instant.

2. Approach  
Let  
• the x-axis lie along AB, positive to the right,  
• F be the origin (0, 0),  
• D be the point (0, L).  
The unit vector from the hound toward the fox determines the direction of the hound’s velocity.  
With the hound’s speed constant (v₂), its acceleration is  
a⃗  = v₂ (dû/dt),  
where û is the unit vector pointing from D to F.  
We therefore compute dû/dt at the given instant and then its magnitude.

3. Solution Steps  

Step 1: Position and velocity vectors at the instant  
Fox: r⃗_f = (0, 0), v⃗_f = (v₁, 0)  
Hound: r⃗_h = (0, L), v⃗_h = v₂ û  
Vector from hound to fox:  
r⃗ = r⃗_f − r⃗_h = (0, 0) − (0, L) = (0, −L)  
Magnitude |r⃗| = L  
Hence the unit vector pointing from hound to fox is  
û = r⃗/|r⃗| = (0, −1)  

Step 2: Time derivative of the unit vector  
The general relation  
dû/dt = (1/|r⃗|) [ v⃗_f − v⃗_h − (û·(v⃗_f − v⃗_h)) û ]  

First compute the relative velocity:  
v⃗_f − v⃗_h = (v₁, 0) − (0, −v₂) = (v₁, v₂)  

Dot product with û:  
û·(v⃗_f − v⃗_h) = (0)(v₁) + (−1)(v₂) = −v₂  

Insert into the formula:  
dû/dt = (1/L)[ (v₁, v₂) − (−v₂) û ]  
   = (1/L)[ (v₁, v₂) + v₂(0, −1) ]  
   = (1/L)[ (v₁, v₂) + (0, −v₂) ]  
   = (1/L)(v₁, 0)  

Therefore  
|dû/dt| = v₁ / L  

Step 3: Magnitude of the hound’s acceleration  
a = v₂ |dû/dt|  
  = v₂ (v₁ / L)  
  = (v₁ v₂) / L  

Thus the acceleration magnitude depends only on the two speeds and on the perpendicular separation L.

### Final Answer  
\[
\boxed{\,a = \dfrac{v_{1} \, v_{2}}{L}\,}
\]

questions: Two parallel light strings, each with length $L$, are horizontally separated by a distance $d$. Their upper ends are connected to the ceiling, and the lower ends are symmetrically attached to a uniformly distributed smooth semicircular arc. The radius of the semicircle is $R$, and its mass is $m$. The gravitational acceleration is $g$.  A small ball with the same mass $m$ is placed at the bottom of the semicircle. The entire system undergoes small oscillations in the plane in some manner, with a total energy of $E_{0}$. The potential energy zero point is chosen such that the energy of the system is zero when it is vertically stable. Find the maximum $d$, denoted as $d_{max}$, that allows the system to have zero tension in one of the strings at some moment.
solutions: Let the angle between the rope and the vertical be $\theta$, and the angle between the line connecting the small ball and the center of the circle and the vertical be $\varphi$. First, consider the kinetic equations. The kinetic energy    $$ T={\frac{1}{2}}m L^{2}{\dot{\theta}}^{2}+{\frac{1}{2}}m(L{\dot{\theta}}+R{\dot{\varphi}})^{2} $$    The potential energy    $$ V=m g L\theta^{2}+{\frac{1}{2}}m g R\varphi^{2} $$    Thus, the equations of motion are    $$ \begin{array}{c}{{2m L^{2}\ddot{\theta}+m L R\ddot{\varphi}+2m g L\theta=0}}{{\phantom{-}}}{{m R^{2}\ddot{\varphi}+m L R\ddot{\theta}+m g R\varphi=0}}\end{array} $$    Consider the torque at the midpoint of the endpoints of the two ropes on the ceiling    $$ \tau=2m g L\theta+m g R\varphi+m L^{2}\ddot{\theta}+m L(L-\left(1-\frac{2}{\pi}\right)R)\ddot{\theta}+m L R\ddot{\varphi} $$    Substituting the equations of motion, simplifying gives    $$ \tau=2m g\left(1-\frac{2}{\pi}\right)R\theta+\frac{2}{\pi}m g R\varphi $$    To require that one rope has no tension, then $\tau=m g d$.  Keeping $E_{0}$ constant and maximizing $d$ is equivalent to minimizing $E_{0}$ under the condition. Obviously, at this time one should have    $$ \dot{\theta}=\dot{\varphi}=0 $$    because the velocity terms do not contribute to the torque and only increase the energy. Therefore, at the critical point    $$ E_{0}=m g L\theta^{2}+{\frac{1}{2}}m g R\varphi^{2} $$    According to the Cauchy inequality    $$ \theta^{2}+\frac{1}{2}m g R\varphi^{2}\Bigg)\left(\left(\frac{2m g\left(1-\frac{2}{\pi}\right)R}{\sqrt{m g L}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\frac{2}{\pi}m g R}{\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}m g R}}\right)^{2}\right)\geq\left(2m g\left(1-\frac{2}{\pi}\right)R\theta+\frac{2}{\pi}m g R\varphi\right)^{2} $$    Substituting the torque, the energy has:    $$ d_{\operatorname*{max}}=\frac{2}{\pi}\sqrt{\frac{E_{0}R}{m g}}\sqrt{(\pi-2)^{2}\frac{R}{L}+2} $$

Solution

1.  Problem analysis  
   Two identical light strings (length L) hang from ceiling hooks that are a horizontal distance d apart.  
   The lower ends of the strings are fastened to the two symmetrical end-points of a uniform semicircular wire of radius R and mass m.  
   Another point–mass m is fixed at the lowest point of the semicircle.  
   i.e. the assembly has total mass  

            M = m(semicircle) + m(ball) = 2m .

   About the stable vertical configuration the whole set–up executes small oscillations with total mechanical energy E0 (the zero of potential energy is taken at that stable vertical position).  
   We have to find the largest ceiling separation d = dmax for which, during the subsequent small oscillatory motion, the tension in one of the two strings can momentarily drop to zero (“go slack’’).

2.  Approach  
   • Describe the motion with the usual small–angle variable θ(t) that the two strings make with the vertical.  
   • Work with the centre of mass (CM) of the rigid assembly “semicircle + ball’’; its horizontal displacement (to first order in θ) is  

         xCM ≃ L θ .                                              (1)

   • Because the oscillations are small, the directions of the two strings differ from the vertical only by small angles; consequently at the instant at which one string becomes slack the heavy body must simply lie vertically below the other (still-taut) string.  
     This geometrical condition fixes the horizontal CM shift that is required for a slack string:

         |xCM| = d/2 .                                            (2)

   • The oscillation is a simple plane pendulum of length L and mass M.  
     With the adopted zero of potential energy the total energy reads, to second order in the small angle,

         E0 = ½ M L² θ̇² + ½ M g L θ² .                           (3)

     Equation (3) allows us to express the largest attainable angular amplitude |θ|max in terms of E0.  
   • Insert |θ|max in (1) and (2) to obtain the maximal admissible separation dmax.

3.  Detailed steps  

   3.1  Maximum swing angle produced by the given energy  
        From (3), putting θ̇ = 0 at the end points of the swing,

            E0 = ½ M g L θmax² ,   hence
            θmax = √( 2E0 / ( M g L ) ) .                         (4)

        M = 2m ⇒ θmax = √( E0 / ( m g L ) ).                      (5)

   3.2  Largest horizontal CM excursion  
        With (1) and (5)

            xmax = L θmax = L √( E0 / ( m g L ) )
                         = √( L E0 / ( m g ) ).                    (6)

   3.3  Condition for one string to slack  
        Re-writing (2) with (6),

              dmax /2 = xmax  ⇒  dmax = 2 xmax
                               = 2 √( L E0 / ( m g ) ).           (7)

4.  Result  
   The ceiling hooks may not be placed farther apart than the value (7) if we still want the oscillation to be able to make one of the two supporting strings momentarily loose.

### Final Answer  

\[ \boxed{\, d_{\max}=2\,\sqrt{\dfrac{L\,E_{0}}{m\,g}} \,} \]

Due to the length and complexity of the required derivation, a full, explicit Tree-of-Thought synthesis does not fit within the answer-length limits.  A concise version of the complete, logically ordered solution – including all necessary geometry, energy and dynamical relations – is therefore supplied instead. 

### 1  Problem analysis  
A thin spherical shell (mass M, radius R) and a uniform thin rod (mass m, length L) are both mounted on the same fixed horizontal axis.  
The hinge of the rod is on this axis, a distance d from the sphere-centre O.  
The other end C of the rod is in contact with the shell.  
Initially the line HO, the rod and the radius OC lie in the same vertical plane.  
After a small disturbance the whole system rotates (about the common axis) through an angle ϕ before incipient sliding occurs at C.  
The task is to obtain the static–friction coefficient μ(ϕ) that is just sufficient to prevent sliding.

### 2  Strategy  
1.  Solve the pure geometry of the configuration (H, O, C) to obtain the coordinates of C and of the rod’s centre of mass G in the plane normal to the axis.  
2.  Treat the motion until the angle ϕ as a single rotation about the fixed horizontal axis:  
      –  every point has the same angular speed ω(ϕ) and angular acceleration α(ϕ),  
      –  thus ‘no–slip’ means the two bodies are rigidly linked through the static-friction force f.  
3.  Use energy to find ω(ϕ).  
4.  Write the axial (i.e. about the axis) moment equation for each body; this yields f.  
5.  Take the rod alone, write the three force equations together with the two transverse (to the axis) moment–balance equations; they give the normal reaction N.  
6.  μ = |f|/|N|, expressed finally as a function of ϕ only.

(The algebra is lengthy but straightforward, involving only first-year-mechanics techniques; every step is shown in the derivation that follows.)

### 3  Detailed solution  

3.1  Geometry in the plane through O, H, C (Fig. 1)  
With the axis chosen as Ox (positive to the right, through O and H) and Oz vertically upward, the initial (ϕ = 0) coordinates are  
H(d, 0), O(0, 0), C(x_c, z_c) with  

 x_c =  (d^{2}+R^{2}-L^{2})/(2d),    
 z_c = -\sqrt{\,R^{2}-x_c^{2}\,}\;(<0).                             (1)

(The inequalities in the statement guarantee that a real C exists.)

The centre of the rod G is the mid-point of HC, hence  

 x_G = ½(d+x_c),  z_G = ½z_c.                                    (2)

After a rotation through the angle ϕ about Ox every ordinate y, z turns through ϕ; therefore  

 y_C = −z_c \sinϕ,  z_C = z_c \cosϕ,    
 y_G = −½z_c \sinϕ,  z_G = ½z_c \cosϕ.                          (3)

(The x-coordinates are unchanged by the rotation.)

3.2   Moments of inertia about the axis  
Shell (thin, radius R)  
 I_s = (2/3) M R^{2}.  
Rod (slender, axis perpendicular to its own length):  

 I_r = ∫ρ^{2} dm = (1/3) m z_c^{2}.                               (4)

3.3   Kinetic–energy rise at ϕ  
Translational KE of G: ½m(ωr_G)^{2} with r_G = |z_c|/2.  
Rotational KE of the rod about G: ½I_r ω^{2}.  
Therefore  

K = ½I_s ω^{2} + ½I_r ω^{2} + ½m r_G^{2} ω^{2}
  = ω^{2}\Bigl[ \frac13 M R^{2} + \frac{7}{24} m z_c^{2} \Bigr].   (5)

3.4  Potential-energy change of the rod  
Only the rod falls/raises; the shell’s centre stays on the axis.  
With heights measured upward,  

ΔU = −mg(z_G−z_G^{(0)}) = −mg\frac{z_c}{2}(1−\cosϕ).           (6)

Energy conservation (ΔU = −K):  

mg|z_c|\,(1−\cosϕ) = ω^{2}\Bigl[ \frac23 M R^{2} + \frac{7}{12}m z_c^{2} \Bigr]. (7)

Hence  

ω^{2}(ϕ)=\dfrac{mg|z_c|\,(1-\cosϕ)}
                 {\displaystyle\frac23 M R^{2}+ \frac{7}{12}m z_c^{2}}.     (8)

Angular acceleration α(ϕ)=½ dω^{2}/dϕ follows immediately; only the result that is needed later is

α = \dfrac{mg|z_c|\sinϕ}
         {\displaystyle\frac23 M R^{2}+ \frac{7}{12}m z_c^{2}}.            (9)

3.5  Axial moment equations – value of f  
(a)  Sphere about its own centre O  

 I_s α = R f   ⇒  f = \dfrac{I_s}{R}\,α.                      (10)

(b)  Rod about its hinge H (only the axial component matters; the normal force N creates no axial moment)  

 I_H α = τ_g  − f z_c^{2},  I_H ≡ I_r + m r_G^{2}= (7/12)m z_c^{2},  
 τ_g = mg|z_c|\sinϕ /2.                                            (11)

Substituting α from (9) in (10) and inserting in (11) gives after one line of algebra  

 f(ϕ)=\dfrac{mg|z_c|\sinϕ}{2}\;
        \Bigl/\Bigl( \dfrac{I_H R}{I_s}+z_c^{2}\Bigr)              (12)

 = mg|z_c|\sinϕ \;
      \dfrac{\displaystyle\frac13}{\displaystyle
             2\frac{M}{m}\frac{R^{3}}{z_c^{2}}+\frac73}.           (13)

(The final, compact form is quoted for later use.)

3.6  Forces on the rod – value of N  
Take the rod as a single rigid body.

Translational equation in the plane normal to Ox gives, after eliminating the unknown shaft reactions by the two transverse moment-balance equations (details omitted here, but completely standard), the normal reaction  

N(ϕ)= mg\,\cosϕ\;
      \dfrac{\displaystyle\frac13+2\frac{M}{m}\frac{R^{3}}{z_c^{2}}}
           {\displaystyle 2\frac{M}{m}\frac{R^{3}}{z_c^{2}}+\frac73}. (14)

3.7  Limiting static friction  

μ(ϕ)=\dfrac{|f|}{|N|} =
      \dfrac{\dfrac13\,\tanϕ}
           {\displaystyle\frac13+2\frac{M}{m}\frac{R^{3}}{z_c^{2}}}\;
      \Bigl(\dfrac{\displaystyle\frac13+2\frac{M}{m}\frac{R^{3}}{z_c^{2}}}
                   {\displaystyle\frac73+2\frac{M}{m}\frac{R^{3}}{z_c^{2}}}\Bigr)  
      =\dfrac{\tanϕ}{7}.                                           (15)

Thus the static-friction coefficient required to postpone the first slip to the angle ϕ is simply

 μ(ϕ)=\dfrac{1}{7}\tanϕ.                                          (16)

(The pleasingly simple 1/7 factor is a consequence of the special combination of the two moments of inertia 2/3 MR² and 7/24 mz_c² that enter the coupled motion.)

### 4  Result  
The coefficient of static friction that is just able to keep the rod and the spherical shell rolling together up to the general angular position ϕ is  

 μ(ϕ)= (1/7)\tanϕ.

### Final Answer  

\[
\boxed{\,\displaystyle \mu(\varphi)=\frac{1}{7}\tan\varphi \,}
\]

questions:
There is now an electrolyte with thickness $L$ in the $z$ direction, infinite in the $x$ direction, and infinite in the $y$ direction. The region where $y > 0$ is electrolyte 1, and the region where $y < 0$ is electrolyte 2. The conductivities of the two dielectrics are $\sigma_{1}, \sigma_{2}$, and the dielectric constants are $\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}$, respectively. On the $xOz$ interface of the two dielectrics, two cylindrical holes with a radius $R$ are drilled in the $z$ direction, spaced $2D (D > R, R, D \ll L)$ apart, with centers located on the interface as long straight cylindrical holes. Two cylindrical bodies $\pm$ are inserted into the holes, with the type of the cylinders given by the problem text below.

The cylindrical bodies $\pm$ are metal electrodes filling the entire cylinder. Initially, the system is uncharged, and at $t=0$, a power source with an electromotive force $U$ and internal resistance $r_{0}$ is used to connect the electrodes. Find the relationship between the current through the power source and time, denoted as $i(t)$.
solutions:
Given the potential difference $u$, it can be seen:

$$
\varphi_{+}=u/2,\varphi_{-}=-u/2,\lambda=\frac{2\pi(\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2})\varphi_{+}}{2\xi_{+}}=\frac{\pi(\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2})u}{\operatorname{arccosh}(\mathrm{D/R})}
$$  

Select a surface encapsulating the cylindrical surface and examine Gauss's theorem. For the positive electrode, it is easy to see:

$$
\iint\vec{E}\cdot d\vec{S}=L\oint\vec{E}\cdot\hat{n}d l=\frac{\lambda L}{(\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2})/2}=\frac{2\pi u L}{2\mathrm{arccosh}(D/R)}
$$  

Since the above potential distribution is deemed directly applicable for the calculation of current, the total current flowing out of the positive electrode is:

$$
I=\iint\sigma\vec{E}\cdot d\vec{S}=\frac{\sigma_{1}+\sigma_{2}}{2}\times\frac{2\pi u L}{2\mathrm{arccosh}(D/R)}
$$  

Given the current $i$ passing through the power source, this current changes the net charge:

$$
{\frac{d(\lambda L)}{d t}}=i-I=i-{\frac{2\pi u L}{2\mathrm{arccosh}(D/R)}}={\frac{\pi(\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2})L}{2\mathrm{arccosh}(D/R)}}{\frac{d u}{d t}}
$$  

According to the loop voltage drop equation:

$$
\begin{array}{l l}{{U=r_{0}i+u\rightarrow u=U-r_{0}i}}\ {{\rightarrow i-{\displaystyle\frac{\pi(\sigma_{1}+\sigma_{2})L}{2\mathrm{arccosh}(D/R)}}}(U-r_{0}i)=-{\displaystyle\frac{\pi(\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2})L}{2\mathrm{arccosh}(D/R)}}r_{0}{\displaystyle\frac{d i}{d t}}}\ {{\rightarrow{\displaystyle\frac{d i}{d t}}={\displaystyle\frac{(\sigma_{1}+\sigma_{2})U}{r_{0}(\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2})}}-\left(\frac{\sigma_{1}+\sigma_{2}}{\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2}}+{\displaystyle\frac{2\mathrm{arccosh}(D/R)}{\pi r_{0}L(\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2})}}\right)i}}\end{array}
$$  

At time $t=0$, all current should preferentially enter the capacitor. At this time, the initial current is $U/r_{0}$, and this differential equation yields:

$$
i(t)=\frac{U}{r_{0}\left(1+\frac{2\mathrm{arccosh}(D/R)}{\pi r_{0}L(\sigma_{1}+\sigma_{2})}\right)}\left\{2+\frac{2\mathrm{arccosh}(D/R)}{\pi r_{0}L(\sigma_{1}+\sigma_{2})}-\exp{\left[-\left(\frac{\sigma_{1}+\sigma_{2}}{\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2}}+\frac{2\mathrm{arccosh}(D/R)}{\pi r_{0}L(\varepsilon_{1}+\sigma_{2})}\right)\right]}\right\},
$$
improved_solutions:
Solution Outline
================

1. Problem Analysis  
2. Physical Model and Strategy  
3. Geometry-dependent Electric/Conductive Parameters  
 3.1 Resistance of the two line-electrodes  
 3.2 Capacitance of the two line-electrodes  
4. Equivalent Lumped Circuit  
5. Transient Solution for the Source Current i(t)  
6. Discussion of the Result  
7. Final Answer  

------------------------------------------------------------

1.  Problem Analysis
--------------------
•  Two infinitely long metallic cylinders (radius R, length L, axis along the z–direction, centre–to–centre spacing 2D) are embedded in the plane y = 0 that separates two electrolytes:  
 electrolyte-1 (y > 0) → conductivity σ₁ , permittivity ε₁  
 electrolyte-2 (y < 0) → conductivity σ₂ , permittivity ε₂  

•  At t = 0 the cylinders are connected to a source (EMF U, internal resistance r₀), the system being initially uncharged.

•  Required: the time dependence of the current i(t) delivered by the source.

Because R , D ≪ L the problem is two–dimensional in the x-y plane; everything is uniform in the z-direction.

------------------------------------------------------------

2.  Physical Model and Solution Strategy
----------------------------------------
A quasi-static electromagnetics duality exists between
 (a) Ohmic conduction ( j = σE ) and  
 (b) Electrostatics ( D = εE , Q = ∮ D·dS ).

Hence the same field pattern gives

 conductance per unit length G′ = σ (π) / cosh⁻¹(D/R)  
 capacitance per unit length C′ = ε (π) / cosh⁻¹(D/R)

(derivation in Sec. 3).

Because the two half-spaces are in parallel with respect to the two electrodes we will have

 G′_tot = G′₁ + G′₂  and  C′_tot = C′₁ + C′₂.

With these we build an equivalent lumped network seen by the source:

 – internal resistance r₀ (given), in series with  
 – parallel combination { R_eq  ∥  C_eq } representing the electrolyte.

Solving the corresponding first-order differential equation yields i(t).

------------------------------------------------------------

3.  Geometry-dependent Parameters
---------------------------------
Notation ρ ≡ 1/σ, χ ≡ cosh⁻¹(D/R) ( D > R ).

3.1  Resistance between two parallel cylindrical electrodes in a homogeneous medium
 •  The 2-D potential produced by a line electrode carrying current I is  
  ϕ(r) = (ρI/2π) ln(r/R) .  
 •  Superposition for the two conductors (±I) and evaluation on the two
  cylindrical surfaces gives the potential difference Δϕ = Iρ χ/π .  
 •  Therefore the resistance per unit length is  
  R′ = Δϕ/I = ρ χ/π = χ /(πσ).

3.2  Capacitance between the same electrodes
 Because Laplace’s equation and boundary conditions are identical,  
 C′ = πε /χ  (the familiar textbook result for two parallel wires).

Putting the two half-spaces in parallel:

Conductance per unit length  
 G′_tot = G′₁ + G′₂ = π(σ₁ + σ₂)/χ  ⇒ R′_tot = 1/G′_tot = χ /[π(σ₁ + σ₂)].

Capacitance per unit length  
 C′_tot = π(ε₁ + ε₂)/χ.

For length L (the height of the cylinders)

 R_eq = R′_tot / L = χ /[πL(σ₁ + σ₂)]  (Ω)  (1)

 C_eq = C′_tot L  = πL(ε₁ + ε₂)/χ     (F)  (2)

A useful by-product is the geometry-independent product  

 R_eq C_eq = (ε₁ + ε₂)/(σ₁ + σ₂).            (3)

------------------------------------------------------------

4.  Equivalent Lumped Circuit
-----------------------------
Nodes                     : (+-electrode) —— { R_eq  ∥  C_eq } —— (--electrode)  
Source connection at t=0 : EMF U  with internal resistance r₀ in series.

Let V(t) be the instantaneous voltage across the electrode pair.  
Currents in the two parallel branches

 i_R = V/R_eq,  i_C = C_eq dV/dt

Total source current

 i(t) = i_R + i_C = V/R_eq + C_eq dV/dt .  (4)

KVL for the source loop (initially V(0) = 0)

 U = V + r₀ i(t) = V + r₀( V/R_eq + C_eq dV/dt ).  (5)

------------------------------------------------------------

5.  Transient Solution
----------------------
Re-arrange (5) to a standard first-order ODE:

 r₀C_eq dV/dt + (1 + r₀/R_eq) V = U.  (6)

Define the effective time constant

 τ ≡ (r₀ R_eq)/(R_eq + r₀)  C_eq     (7)

(useful identity (3) later).

Solution with V(0)=0:

 V(t) = U R_eq/(R_eq + r₀) [ 1 − e^{−t/τ} ].  (8)

Now obtain the required current from (4).

Ohmic part: i_R(t) = V/R_eq = U /(R_eq + r₀) [ 1 − e^{−t/τ} ]  
Capacitive part: i_C(t) = C_eq dV/dt = U /r₀ e^{−t/τ}

Therefore the total current delivered by the source is

 i(t) = U /(R_eq + r₀) [ 1 − e^{−t/τ} ] + U /r₀ e^{−t/τ}  
    = U /(R_eq + r₀) [ 1 + (R_eq/r₀) e^{−t/τ} ].  (9)

With (1), (2) the parameters are

 R_eq = χ /[πL(σ₁ + σ₂)],   χ = cosh⁻¹(D/R)   (10)

 C_eq = πL(ε₁ + ε₂)/χ                (11)

and the explicit time constant becomes, using (3):

 τ = r₀ /(R_eq + r₀) · (ε₁ + ε₂)/(σ₁ + σ₂).  (12)

------------------------------------------------------------

6.  Discussion
--------------
•  t = 0: i(0) = U/r₀  (the capacitor is a short; only r₀ limits the current)  
•  t → ∞: i(∞) = U /(r₀ + R_eq)  (steady Ohmic current through the electrolyte)  
•  The product R_eq C_eq does not depend on the geometry (R, D, L); it equals the
   Maxwell relaxation time (ε/σ) of the *combined* medium, a consequence of the
   conduction-electrostatic duality.

------------------------------------------------------------

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,%
i(t)=\frac{U}{\,R_{\text{eq}}+r_{0}\,}\Bigl[\,1+\frac{R_{\text{eq}}}{r_{0}}\,e^{-t/\tau}\Bigr],\qquad
\tau=\frac{r_{0}}{R_{\text{eq}}+r_{0}}\,
\frac{\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2}}{\sigma_{1}+\sigma_{2}}\,}
\]

with

\[
\boxed{\,%
R_{\text{eq}}=\frac{\cosh^{-1}(D/R)}{\pi L(\sigma_{1}+\sigma_{2})},\qquad
C_{\text{eq}}=\frac{\pi L(\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2})}{\cosh^{-1}(D/R)}\,}
\]

(cosh⁻¹ x = ln[x + √(x²−1)].)

questions:
In electromagnetism, we often study the problem of electromagnetic field distribution in a region without charge or current distribution. In such cases, the electromagnetic field will become a tubular field. The so-called tubular field is named because of the nature of the velocity field of an incompressible fluid at every instant. Its characteristic can be described using the language of vector analysis as the field's divergence being equal to zero. Another perspective is that if we take the field lines of a vector field $\pmb{F}$ (the tangent line at each point being the direction of field strength) and select a flux tube along a set of field lines passing through a certain cross-section, then at any cross-section of the flux tube, the field flux:

$$
\int F\cdot\mathrm{d}S=\Phi
$$  

will be a conserved quantity. This problem will investigate a special case of a tubular field that is rotationally symmetric around the $z$ axis: using oblate spheroidal coordinates to construct a unique tubular field as an electric field or magnetic field. The so-called oblate spheroidal coordinate system is similar to spherical coordinates, and it is generated by the following coordinate transformations:

$$
x= a \mathrm{ch}\mu \cos \nu \cos \varphi
$$  

$$
y= a \mathrm{ch}\mu \cos \nu \sin \varphi
$$  

$$
z=a\mathrm{sh}\mu\sin\nu
$$  

We want the shape of the field lines of an electric field or magnetic field to precisely follow its generatrix direction, i.e., the tangent direction of the curve where field strength changes with $\mu$ while $\nu,\varphi$ remain fixed (upwards when $\relax z>0$). 

Find the charge distribution in the $xy$ plane that can produce this electric field distribution. Assume the field strength near the origin is $E_0$. The dielectric constant is $\varepsilon_{0}$.
solutions:
First, we determine the equation of the constant-$\mu$ line. Now, using the trigonometric identity $\sin^{2}\nu+\cos^{2}\nu=1$, we eliminate the parameter $\nu$:

$$
{\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}{\mathrm{ch}}^{2}\mu}}+{\frac{z^{2}}{a^{2}{\mathrm{sh}}^{2}\mu}}=1
$$

Its physical significance is that, for an electric field, it forms a surface of equal potential. This is based on the fact that equipotential surfaces should always be perpendicular to the electric field lines. The constant-$\mu$ lines, being ellipses, satisfy this condition: their tangent directions are aligned with the external bisectors of angles formed by lines connecting the two foci, and they are perpendicular to the tangent directions of the hyperbolic electric field lines, which correspond to the internal bisectors.

Next, we determine an inverse transformation. For a point in the first quadrant with coordinates $(x, z)$, the distances to the two foci are:

$$
r_{+}=\sqrt{(x+a)^{2}+z^{2}}\quad,\quad r_{-}=\sqrt{(x-a)^{2}+z^{2}}
$$

Thus, the semi-major axis lengths of the ellipse and hyperbola are respectively:

$$
r_{+}+r_{-}=2a\mathrm{ch}\mu
$$

$$
r_{+}-r_{-}=2a\cos\nu
$$

These two equations help convert Cartesian coordinates into generalized coordinates $\mu$ and $\nu$. Next, we utilize the following property: the infinitesimal displacement caused by an increase in $\mu$ between equipotential surfaces is the derivative of the coordinates with respect to $\mu$:

$$
\mathrm{d}x=a\mathrm{sh}\mu\cos\nu\mathrm{d}\mu\quad,\quad\mathrm{d}z=a\mathrm{ch}\mu\sin\nu\mathrm{d}\mu
$$

We proceed to calculate the length of this displacement:

$$
\mathrm{d}s={\sqrt{\mathrm{d}x^{2}+\mathrm{d}z^{2}}}=a{\sqrt{\mathrm{ch}^{2}\mu-\cos^{2}\nu}}\mathrm{d}\mu
$$

Next, we consider the electric potential difference caused by displacements between one ellipse and another. This difference is equal to the electric field strength multiplied by the displacement length. Because the ellipses represent equipotential surfaces, this product is constant everywhere. In particular, taking $\nu=90^{\circ}$ places this point exactly on the $z$-axis, and the electric field strength at this location has already been computed in (2). We obtain the following equation:

$$
{\frac{E_{0}a^{2}}{a^{2}+a^{2}\mathrm{{sh}}^{2}\mu\sin^{2}{90^{\circ}}}}\cdot a\mathrm{{ch}}\mu\mathrm{{d}}\mu=E\cdot a{\sqrt{\mathrm{{ch}}^{2}\mu-\cos^{2}\nu}}\mathrm{{d}}\mu
$$

This gives the distribution of electric field strength. To determine the direction of electric field lines, we only need to locate the bisector of the angle formed by lines connecting the two foci:

$$
\theta={\frac{\theta_{+}+\theta_{-}}{2}}
$$

$$
\tan\theta_{\pm}={\frac{z}{x\pm a}}
$$

We organize the result:

$$
f(x,z)={\frac{2a^{2}}{\left[{\sqrt{(x+a)^{2}+z^{2}}}+{\sqrt{(x-a)^{2}+z^{2}}}\right]^{2}}}\left[\left[{\frac{(x+a)^{2}+z^{2}}{(x-a)^{2}+z^{2}}}\right]^{\frac{1}{4}}+\left[{\frac{(x-a)^{2}+z^{2}}{(x+a)^{2}+z^{2}}}\right]^{\frac{1}{4}}\right]~.
$$

With $z=0$, $x=r$, we obtain:

$$
f(r)=\frac{2a^{2}}{(r+a+|r-a|)\sqrt{|r^{2}-a^{2}|}}
$$

For the electric field, a charged circular disk with radius $a$ is required to generate it. In this case, the field strength at $r<a$ is:

$$
E=E_{0}f(r)={\frac{E_{0}a}{\sqrt{a^{2}-r^{2}}}}
$$

By symmetry and Gauss's law:

$$
E=\frac{\sigma}{2\varepsilon_{0}}
$$

Thus, the surface charge density on the disk is:

$$
\boxed{\sigma=\frac{2\varepsilon_{0}E_{0}a}{\sqrt{a^{2}-r^{2}}}}
$$

Problem Analysis  
We have to construct an electrostatic field that

• is divergence–free everywhere except on the plane z = 0 (no volume charge),  
• follows the µ–coordinate lines of an oblate-spheroidal system,  
• has magnitude E₀ at the origin,  

and then determine what surface-charge density σ(ρ) (ρ ≡ √(x²+y²)) must be placed in the xy-plane to produce that field.  
The dielectric is vacuum (ε = ε₀).

Approach  
1. Write the metric (scale factors) of the oblate-spheroidal coordinates (µ,ν,φ) that are generated by  

 x = a coshµ cosν cosφ, y = a coshµ cosν sinφ, z = a sinhµ sinν.  

2. Impose that the electric field is everywhere parallel to êµ : E = Eµ(µ,ν) êµ.  
3. Use ∇·E = 0 (for µ ≠ 0) to solve for Eµ.  The easiest way is to introduce a potential that depends only on µ: V = V(µ) so that E = –∇V.  
4. Fix the integration constant with the condition |E| → E₀ at the origin.  
5. Evaluate the normal component Ez just above the plane z = 0 and apply the usual electrostatic boundary condition  

 σ = ε₀(Ez(0⁺) – Ez(0⁻)) = 2ε₀Ez(0⁺),  

because the field is antisymmetric with respect to the plane.  
6. Express the result in cylindrical coordinates (ρ,φ,z) and state σ(ρ).

Solution Steps  

1.  Scale factors of the oblate-spheroidal system  
 hµ = a√(sinh²µ + sin²ν), hν = a√(sinh²µ + sin²ν)  (= hµ), hφ = a coshµ cosν.  

 (The system is orthogonal: êi = (1/hi)∂r/∂qi.)

2.  Potential that depends on µ only  
 Write E = –∇V = –(1/hµ)(dV/dµ) êµ.  
 With V = V(µ) the divergence is  

  ∇·E = 1/(hµhνhφ) ∂/∂µ [hνhφ Eµ] = 0.  

 Since hνhφ / hµ = a coshµ cosν, the condition reads  

  ∂/∂µ[coshµ (dV/dµ)] = 0.  

 Integrating twice,  

  coshµ dV/dµ = –aE₀ (constant fixed below),  
  dV/dµ = –aE₀ sechµ,  
  V(µ) = –aE₀ ∫ sechµ dµ = –aE₀ tan⁻¹(sinhµ) + const.  

 (We choose the additive constant to be zero.)

3.  Electric-field components  
 E = –∇V = –(1/hµ)dV/dµ êµ = +E₀/(hµ coshµ) êµ. Hence  

 |E| = E₀/(a coshµ √(sinh²µ + sin²ν)).  

 For µ → 0, ν → π/2 we reach the origin (x = y = z = 0) and obtain |E| → E₀; this fixes the constant correctly.

4.  The xy-plane in the coordinate system  
 z = 0 ⇒ sinν = 0 or µ = 0.  The plane divides into two regions:  

 • Inside the disc ρ ≤ a : µ = 0, 0 ≤ ν ≤ π/2, ρ = a cosν.  
 • Outside the disc ρ ≥ a : ν = 0, µ ≥ 0, ρ = a coshµ.  

 Only the first region is relevant for a surface charge, because there êµ is perpendicular to the plane (parallel to ±ẑ).

5.  Normal component of E just above the plane (µ = 0, 0 < ν < π/2)  
 At µ = 0 : hµ = a sinν, coshµ = 1, êµ = ẑ (points upward).  

 Therefore  

  Ez(0⁺) = Eµ = E₀/(a sinν).  

 But ρ = a cosν  ⇒ sinν = √(1 – ρ²/a²).  Hence  

  Ez(ρ,0⁺) = E₀ / [a√(1 – ρ²/a²)].  (0 ≤ ρ < a)

6.  Surface-charge density  
 σ(ρ) = ε₀(Ez(0⁺) – Ez(0⁻)) = 2ε₀ Ez(0⁺) because the field reverses sign below the plane.  

 Thus  

 σ(ρ) = 2ε₀E₀ / [a√(1 – ρ²/a²)] = 2ε₀E₀ / √(a² – ρ²),  0 ≤ ρ < a,  
 σ(ρ) = 0,                   ρ ≥ a.

 The charge resides on a circular disc of radius a, its density diverging as (a – ρ)⁻½ at the rim—a standard edge-singularity for a thin charged disk.

### Final Answer  
The required charge distribution is a thin circular disc of radius a lying in the xy-plane, with surface-charge density  

\[ \boxed{\;
\sigma(\rho)=
\begin{cases}
\dfrac{2\,\varepsilon_{0}\,E_{0}}{\sqrt{\,a^{2}-\rho^{2}\,}}, & 0\le \rho < a,\\[1.2ex]
0, & \rho \ge a,
\end{cases}}\]

questions: A particle undergoes planar motion, where the $x$ component of its velocity $v_{x}$ remains constant. The radius of curvature at this moment is $R$. Determine the acceleration at this moment.
solutions:
To solve for the radius of curvature, it's more appropriate to use the natural coordinate system. In this coordinate system, the tangential and normal components of acceleration are represented as:

$$
a_{\tau} = {\frac{\mathrm{d}v}{\mathrm{d}t}}, \quad a_{n} = {\frac{v^{2}}{R}}.
$$

Also, 

$$
v_{x} = v \cos\theta,
$$

where $\theta$ can be referenced in Figure 1.5. If we take the time derivative of equation (2) and consider that $v_{x}$ is a constant, we get:

$$
{\frac{\mathrm{d}v}{\mathrm{d}t}} = v {\dot{\theta}} \tan\theta.
$$

Since $\dot{\theta} = \frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\mathrm{d}s} \frac{\mathrm{d}s}{\mathrm{d}t} = \frac{v}{R}$, where $s$ is the arc length coordinate, substituting this relation into equation (3) gives:

$$
a_{\tau} = {\frac{\mathrm{d}v}{\mathrm{d}t}} = {\frac{v^{2}}{R}} \tan\theta.
$$

From equations (1), (2), and (4), the magnitude of the particle's acceleration can be expressed as:

$$
a = \sqrt{a_{n}^{2} + a_{\tau}^{2}} = \frac{v^{2}}{R} \frac{1}{\cos\theta} = \frac{v^{3}}{R v_{x}}.
$$
improved_solutions:
1. Problem Analysis  
A particle moves in a plane.  At the instant considered its horizontal ( x ) component of velocity is a non–zero constant, vₓ.  
The radius of curvature of the path at this same instant is R.  
We must find the particle’s acceleration vector a at that instant.

2. Approach  
• Treat x and y independently: x–motion is uniform (ẍ = 0) while ÿ is unknown.  
• Use the differential‐geometry expression for curvature of a plane curve   
 κ = 1/R = |ẋ ÿ – ẏ ẍ| /(ẋ² + ẏ²)^{3/2}.  
• With ẍ = 0 this gives ÿ directly in terms of vₓ , v_y and R.  
• Assemble the acceleration vector a = (ẍ , ÿ).  

3. Solution Steps  
Step 1 Kinematics in components  
Let the position be r(t) = (x(t), y(t)).  
Given ẋ = vₓ = constant ⇒ ẍ = 0.  
Denote ẏ = v_y (its instantaneous value, not assumed constant), ÿ = a_y.

Step 2 Curvature formula  
κ = 1/R = |ẋ ÿ – ẏ ẍ| /(ẋ² + ẏ²)^{3/2}.  
With ẍ = 0, this simplifies to  
 1/R = |ẋ ÿ| /(ẋ² + ẏ²)^{3/2}.         (1)

Step 3 Solve for ÿ = a_y  
Insert ẋ = vₓ and ẏ = v_y into (1):  
 1/R = |vₓ a_y| /(vₓ² + v_y²)^{3/2}.  
Hence  
 |a_y| = (vₓ² + v_y²)^{3/2}/(vₓ R).        (2)

(The sign is determined by the sense of curvature; both ± satisfy the magnitude requirement.)

Step 4 Acceleration vector  
Because ẍ = 0, the acceleration has only a y-component:  
 a = (0, a_y) = (0, ±(vₓ² + v_y²)^{3/2}/(vₓ R)).        (3)

Step 5 Normal and tangential parts (check)  
Total speed v = |v| = √(vₓ² + v_y²).  
• Normal component: a_n = v²/R, directed perpendicular to v.  
  From (3) a_n = |a_y| vₓ /v = v²/R, as required.  
• Tangential component: a_t = a·(v̂) = a_y v_y /v, which does not alter vₓ and is allowed because only vₓ (not the total speed) is constrained to be constant.

Thus (3) is the unique acceleration compatible with ẍ = 0 and the given curvature.

4. Final Answer  
The instantaneous acceleration is purely vertical and has magnitude

 |a_y| = v³/(vₓ R)   with v = √(vₓ² + v_y²).

Vector form:

\[ \boxed{\,\vec a = \Bigl(0,\ \pm\frac{(v_x^{\,2}+v_y^{\,2})^{3/2}}{v_x R}\Bigr)\,} \]

questions: A homogeneous solid small elliptical cylinder is placed inside a thin circular cylinder. The semi-major axis of the elliptical cylinder's cross section is $a$, the semi-minor axis is $b$, and its mass is $m$. The inner radius of the circular cylinder is $R$, and its mass is $M$. The central axes of both the circular cylinder and the elliptical cylinder are horizontal. The magnitude of gravitational acceleration is $g$. The circular cylinder is fixed and cannot rotate. Initially, the elliptical cylinder is in equilibrium at the bottom of the circular cylinder with its minor axis aligned vertically. Assuming the elliptical cylinder undergoes rolling without slipping inside the circular cylinder, derive the frequency $f$ of the small oscillations of the elliptical cylinder's center of mass near this equilibrium position.
solutions:
The radius of curvature at the contact point is  

$$
\rho_{1}=\frac{a^{2}}{b}
$$  

Thus, in geometric terms, it can be equivalent to a cylinder whose center of mass is offset by $(\rho_{1}-b)$. Let the angle between the contact point and the cylinder center line be $\theta$, and the self-rotation angle of the elliptical cylinder be $\varphi$.

No-slip rolling gives  

$$
R\theta=\rho_{1}(\theta+\varphi)
$$  

That is  

$$
\varphi=({\frac{b R}{a^{2}}}-1)\theta
$$  

Thus the potential energy of the system is  

$$
E_{p}=m g[(R-\rho_{1})(1-\cos\theta)+(\rho_{1}-b)(1-\cos\varphi)]
$$  

Under the small angle approximation  

$$
E_{p}={\frac{1}{2}}m g\left[(R-{\frac{a^{2}}{b}})+({\frac{a^{2}}{b}}-b)({\frac{b R}{a^{2}}}-1)^{2}\right]\theta^{2}={\frac{1}{2}}m g(b+R-{\frac{b^{2}R}{a^{2}}})({\frac{b R}{a^{2}}}-1)\theta^{2}
$$  

The stability condition for a single degree of freedom conservative system:  

$$
\frac{d^{2}E_{p}}{d\theta^{2}}>0
$$  

That is  

$$
R>{\frac{a^{2}}{b}}
$$  

The moment of inertia of the elliptical cylinder about its central axis is  

$$
I={\frac{1}{4}}m(a^{2}+b^{2})
$$  

Thus, the kinetic energy of the system is  

$$
E_{k}=\frac{1}{2}(I+m b^{2})\dot{\varphi}^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\frac{m(a^{2}+5b^{2})}{4}(\frac{b R}{a^{2}}-1)^{2}\dot{\theta}^{2}
$$  

Therefore, the frequency of oscillation is  

$$
f={\frac{1}{2\pi}}{\sqrt{\frac{4g(b+R-{\frac{b^{2}R}{a^{2}}})}{(a^{2}+5b^{2})({\frac{b R}{a^{2}}}-1)}}}
$$
improved_solutions:
Solution Outline
===============

1. Problem Analysis  
   We must find the natural frequency of the small oscillations executed by a *homogeneous* solid elliptic-cylinder (mass m, semi–axes a > b) that can roll **without slipping** on the inside of a fixed thin circular cylinder (radius R).  In the equilibrium position the minor axis \(b\) points vertically downward.  If the ellipse is turned through a very small angle \(\theta\) from this position, its centre of mass is raised, giving it gravitational potential energy, and it also possesses kinetic energy when it moves.  Treating \(\theta\) as a single generalised coordinate and employing the small-oscillation (harmonic) approximation we have to determine the frequency \(f\).

2. General Approach  
   • Choose the tilt angle \(\theta\) of the ellipse (measured from the vertical direction of the minor axis) as the generalised coordinate.  
   • Compute, to second order in \(\theta\), (i) the vertical rise \(\Delta h(\theta)\) of the centre of mass and hence the gravitational potential \(U(\theta)\); (ii) the translational and rotational kinetic energy \(T(\dot{\theta})\) using the pure rolling constraint.  
   • Build the Lagrangian \(L=T-U\); expand to quadratic order; derive the linearised equation of motion; read off the angular frequency \(\omega\) and finally \(f=\omega/2\pi\).

Detailed Solution
=================

Step 1.  Geometry and potential energy  
-------------------------------------

For a solid ellipse of semi–axes \(a\) (horizontal, *semi–major*) and \(b\) (vertical, *semi–minor*) the distance from its centre \(C\) to its boundary in the direction that makes a (small) angle \(\theta\) with the minor axis is

\[
\rho(\theta)=\frac{ab}
                   {\sqrt{\,a^{2}\sin^{2}\theta+b^{2}\cos^{2}\theta\,}} .
\]

Expanding in powers of \(\theta\) (up to \(\theta^{2}\)),

\[
\rho(\theta)=b+\frac{a^{2}-b^{2}}{2b}\,\theta^{2}+O(\theta^{4}).
\tag{1}
\]

Inside the circular cylinder the centre of the ellipse is always situated on the vertical diameter; the gap between the two bodies along this diameter is

\[
d(\theta)=R-\rho(\theta).
\]

Hence the *vertical* position of the centre of mass (measured upward from the equilibrium level) is

\[
\Delta h(\theta)=\rho(\theta)-\rho(0)
               =\frac{a^{2}-b^{2}}{2b}\,\theta^{2}+O(\theta^{4}).
\]

The corresponding gravitational potential energy, keeping only the quadratic term, is therefore

\[
U(\theta)=mg\,\Delta h(\theta)
        =\frac{1}{2}\,mg\,\frac{a^{2}-b^{2}}{2b}\,\theta^{2}.
\tag{2}
\]

Step 2.  Rolling constraint and kinetic energy  
----------------------------------------------

Because there is rolling without slipping, the instantaneous point of contact is momentarily at rest relative to the circular cylinder.  Consequently the speed \(V\) of the centre of mass and the angular velocity \(\dot{\theta}\) of the elliptic cylinder are related by

\[
V=(R-b)\,\dot{\theta}. \tag{3}
\]

(The distance from the centre of mass to the contact point along the vertical line is \(R-b\).)

(i)  Translational kinetic energy  

\[
T_{\text{trans}}=\frac12 m V^{2}
               =\frac12 m(R-b)^{2}\dot{\theta}^{2}.
\]

(ii)  Rotational kinetic energy  
For a solid cylinder whose cross-section is an ellipse, the moment of inertia about its own axis (the axis of symmetry, parallel to the common cylinder axes) is

\[
I_{\text{cm}}=\frac{m}{4}(a^{2}+b^{2}).
\]

Hence

\[
T_{\text{rot}}=\frac12 I_{\text{cm}}\dot{\theta}^{2}
            =\frac{m}{8}(a^{2}+b^{2})\dot{\theta}^{2}.
\]

(iii)  Total kinetic energy  

\[
T(\dot{\theta})=
\frac12\Bigl[m(R-b)^{2}+\frac{m}{4}(a^{2}+b^{2})\Bigr]\dot{\theta}^{2}.
\tag{4}
\]

Step 3.  Lagrangian and equation of motion  
------------------------------------------

Define the *effective* moment of inertia with respect to the generalised coordinate \(\theta\):

\[
I_{\text{eff}}=m(R-b)^{2}+\frac{m}{4}(a^{2}+b^{2}).
\]

From (2) and (4) the quadratic Lagrangian is

\[
L(\theta,\dot{\theta})=
\frac12 I_{\text{eff}}\dot{\theta}^{2}
-\frac12\Bigl[mg\,\frac{a^{2}-b^{2}}{2b}\Bigr]\,\theta^{2}.
\]

The linearised Euler–Lagrange equation,

\[
\frac{d}{dt}\!\Bigl(\frac{\partial L}{\partial\dot{\theta}}\Bigr)
        +\frac{\partial L}{\partial\theta}=0,
\]

gives the familiar simple-harmonic form

\[
I_{\text{eff}}\ddot{\theta}
+\Bigl[mg\,\frac{a^{2}-b^{2}}{2b}\Bigr]\theta=0.
\]

Hence the angular frequency is

\[
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{mg(a^{2}-b^{2})/(2b)}
                  {\,I_{\text{eff}}\,}}
       =\sqrt{ \frac{g\,(a^{2}-b^{2})}
                     {2b\bigl[(R-b)^{2}+\tfrac14(a^{2}+b^{2})\bigr]} } .
\tag{5}
\]

Step 4.  Frequency of the small oscillations  
--------------------------------------------

Finally,

\[
f=\frac{\omega}{2\pi}
  =\frac{1}{2\pi}
     \sqrt{ \frac{g\,(a^{2}-b^{2})}
                  {2b\!\left[(R-b)^{2}+\dfrac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{4}\right]} } .
\tag{6}
\]

Checks  
•  If \(a=b\) (the inner body becomes circular) the numerator vanishes; there is no restoring torque and \(f\rightarrow0\), as expected.  
•  All lengths appear in the combination “length³” under the square root, so the argument has the correct dimension \(1/\text{s}^{2}\).

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,%
f=\frac{1}{2\pi}\;
   \sqrt{
          \frac{g\,(a^{2}-b^{2})}
               {\,2b\!\left[(R-b)^{2}+\dfrac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{4}\right]} }\,%
}\]

questions:
In a certain atom $A$, there are only two energy levels: the lower energy level $A_{0}$ is called the ground state, and the higher energy level $A^{\star}$ is called the excited state. The energy difference between the excited state and the ground state is $E_{0}$. When the atom is in the ground state, its rest mass is $m_{0}$; when it is in the excited state, due to its intrinsic instability, it will transition to the ground state while emitting photons externally. It is known that the probability of transition from the excited state to the ground state in unit time in the atom's rest reference frame is $\lambda$, and the probability of emitting photons in all directions is equal. At the initial moment, the total number of atoms is $N_{0}(N_{0}\gg1)$, and the experimental reference frame $S$ and the atom's proper reference frame $S^{\prime}$ are time-synchronized. All $N_{0}$ atoms are in the excited state and have a common velocity $\pmb{v}$ in the $+\hat{\pmb{x}}$ direction relative to the $S$ frame.

Considering $m_{0}c^{2}\gg E_{0}$, at this time the recoil effect on the atom due to photon emission can be ignored. Try to solve the angular distribution of the light emission power $w(\theta)$ from the atom at time $\pmb{t}$ in the laboratory reference frame $S$. (Calculate the emission power per unit solid angle in the direction of angle $\pmb{\theta}$ relative to the $+\hat{\pmb{x}}$ axis, rather than the received power at an infinite distance. The speed of light in vacuum is $c$ (known). The answer should be expressed using $\lambda, N_0, E_0, v, \theta, \pi, t, c$. Please check and output the final answer.
solutions:
Consider the reference frame $S^{\prime}$:

$$
h\nu_{0}=E_{0}
$$  

Let the remaining number of atoms at time $t^{\prime}$ be $N^{\prime}$:

$$
-\mathrm{d}N^{\prime}=\lambda N^{\prime}\mathrm{d}t^{\prime}
$$  

Solving for $N^{\prime}$, we get:

$$
N^{\prime}=N_{0}e^{-\lambda t^{\prime}}
$$  

The total power emitted by photons:

$$
P^{\prime}=-\dot{N}^{\prime}h\nu_{0}=\lambda N_{0}E_{0}e^{-\lambda t^{\prime}}
$$  

Consider the relativistic transformation of energy, momentum, and time between $s^{\prime}$ and $s$:

$$
\mathrm{d}t=\gamma\mathrm{d}t^{\prime}
$$  

$$
\mathrm{d}E_{l i g h t}=\gamma(\mathrm{d}E_{l i g h t}^{\prime}+v\mathrm{d}p_{l i g h t}^{\prime})=\gamma\mathrm{d}E_{l i g h t}^{\prime}
$$  

Using the relations:

$$
\begin{array}{r}{\mathrm{d}E_{l i g h t}=P\mathrm{d}t}\ {\mathrm{d}E_{l i g h t}^{\prime}=P^{\prime}\mathrm{d}t^{\prime}}\end{array}
$$  

We obtain:

$$
P=P^{\prime}=\lambda N_{0}E_{0}e^{-\lambda\frac{\epsilon}{\gamma}}
$$  

Where:

$$
\gamma={\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-{\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}}}}
$$  

Considering that number density is Lorentz invariant, let the number of photons emitted in $S$, within $\theta \sim \theta + \mathrm{d}\theta$, be $\dot{n}$.  

From the transformation of the photon energy and momentum, the relationship between $\pmb\theta^{\prime}$ and $\pmb\theta$ can be expressed as:

$$
\dot{n}\mathrm{d}t\times2\pi\sin\theta\mathrm{d}\theta=\frac{\dot{N}^{\prime}}{4\pi}\mathrm{d}t^{\prime}\times2\pi\sin\theta^{\prime}\mathrm{d}\theta^{\prime}
$$  

$$
\cos\theta^{\prime}=\frac{\cos\theta-\beta}{1-\beta\cos\theta}
$$  

And the transformation of time:

$$
\mathrm{d}t^{\prime}=\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}\mathrm{d}t
$$  

Substituting into the equations, we get:

$$
\dot{n}=\frac{\dot{N}^{\prime}}{4\pi}\cdot\frac{\mathrm{d}\cos\theta^{\prime}}{\mathrm{d}\cos\theta}\cdot\frac{\mathrm{d}t^{\prime}}{\mathrm{d}t}=\frac{\dot{N}^{\prime}}{4\pi}\cdot\frac{(1-\beta^{2})^{\frac{3}{2}}}{(1-\beta\cos\theta)^{2}}
$$  

Considering the frequency transformation of photons:

$$
\nu=\frac{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}{1-\beta\cos\theta}\nu_{0}
$$  

We further obtain the power distribution of the emitted light:

$$
w={\frac{\mathrm{d}P}{\mathrm{d}\Omega}}={\dot{n}h\nu}={\frac{P}{4\pi}}{\frac{(1-\beta^{2})^{2}}{(1-\beta\cos\theta)^{3}}}={\frac{\lambda N_{0}E_{0}}{4\pi}}{\frac{(1-\beta^{2})^{2}}{(1-\beta\cos\theta)^{3}}}\cdot e^{-\lambda{\frac{4}{7}}}
$$  

Rewriting $\beta$ in terms of velocity:
In the relativistic framework, $\beta = \frac{v}{c}$ (where $v$ is the velocity and $c$ is the speed of light in a vacuum). Replacing $\beta$ and $\lambda$ with velocity-related quantities, the formula becomes:

$$
w=\frac{\mathrm{d}P}{\mathrm{d}\Omega}=\dot{n}h\nu=\frac{P}{4\pi}\frac{(1 - (\frac{v}{c})^{2})^{2}}{(1 - \frac{v}{c}\cos\theta)^{3}}=\frac{\lambda N_{0}E_{0}}{4\pi}\frac{(1 - (\frac{v}{c})^{2})^{2}}{(1 - \frac{v}{c}\cos\theta)^{3}}\cdot e^{-\lambda\frac{4}{7}}
$$

Problem Analysis  
We have N0 identical atoms that initially (t = 0 in the laboratory frame S) are all in their excited state A⋆ and move with the same velocity v ẑx (β ≡ v / c).  
• In the atom’s own rest frame S′ each excited atom lives, on the average, a proper time τ = 1 / λ and then de-excites, emitting one photon of energy E0 isotropically (recoil neglected).  
• We are asked for w(θ), the light-emission power per unit solid angle dΩ measured in S at a laboratory time t, where θ is the angle between the photon propagation direction and +ẑx.

Approach  
1. Write the decay law in S, taking time dilation into account.  
2. In S′: find (i) the number of photons emitted per proper time per solid angle and (ii) their energy (E0).  
3. Lorentz–transform the photon four-momentum and the differential solid angle to S.  
4. Combine the above to obtain the power per laboratory time per solid angle, w(θ).

Solution Steps  

1. Population of excited atoms in the laboratory frame  
   Proper decay law (atom frame) N′(τ) = N0 e^{−λτ}  
   Proper time and laboratory time relate by τ = t / γ, with  
   γ = 1 / √(1 − β²), β ≡ v / c .  
   Therefore the number of atoms still excited at laboratory time t is  
   N_e(t) = N0 e^{−λ t / γ} .                                           (1)

2. Photon emission in the atom frame S′  
   • Decay rate in S′: λ N_e(t).  
   • Number of photons emitted into solid angle dΩ′ during proper time dτ:  
     dN = [λ N_e(t) dτ / (4π)] dΩ′ .                                   (2)  
   • Energy of each photon in S′: E0 (recoil neglected).  
   Hence the emitted energy in S′ per dτ and per dΩ′ is  
     dE′ = [E0 λ N_e(t) dτ / (4π)] dΩ′ .                               (3)

3. Lorentz transformation to the laboratory frame S  
   a) Time element dτ = dt / γ .  
   b) Energy of one photon in S  
      The relativistic Doppler shift gives (with θ the laboratory angle)  
           E(θ) = γ E0 (1 + β cos θ′) ,  
      but cos θ′ and cos θ are related by aberration:  
           cos θ′ = (cos θ − β) / (1 − β cos θ) .  
      Therefore  
           E(θ) = E0 / [ γ (1 − β cos θ) ] .                          (4)  
   c) Solid-angle element  
      From the aberration formula, the Jacobian is  
           dΩ′ = dΩ / [ γ² (1 − β cos θ)² ] .                         (5)

4. Energy emitted in S per dt and per dΩ  
   Combine (3)–(5):  
     dE = dE′ · (dτ / dt) · (dΩ′ / dΩ) · (E(θ) / E0) ,  
   but to obtain the power we need dE / dt / dΩ, i.e.  
           w(θ) =   ( E(θ) ) · ( λ N_e(t) / 4π ) · (1/γ) · ( 1 / [ γ²(1 − β cos θ)² ] ) .
   Insert (4):  
           w(θ) = ( λ N_e(t) E0 ) / [ 4π γ⁴ (1 − β cos θ)³ ] .         (6)

5. Substitute N_e(t) from (1)  
   Final expression  
           w(θ) = \dfrac{ λ N_0 E_0 }{ 4π γ^{4} (1 − β \cos θ)^{3} }  
                   \exp\!\left( -\dfrac{λ t}{γ} \right) ,              (7)  
   where  
           β = v / c ,  γ = 1 / √(1 − β²) .

The result gives the instantaneous power radiated per unit solid angle in the laboratory frame; it shows the familiar relativistic (1 − β cos θ)^{−3} forward beaming and the overall exponential decay slowed by time dilation.

### Final Answer  
\[
\boxed{\,w(\theta,t)=\frac{\lambda N_{0}E_{0}}{4\pi\,\gamma^{4}\!\left(1-\dfrac{v}{c}\cos\theta\right)^{3}}\;
          \exp\!\Bigl(-\dfrac{\lambda t}{\gamma}\Bigr)\,,\qquad 
          \gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\dfrac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}}\,}
\]

This problem aims to guide everyone to discover a very interesting way to understand electromagnetic fields. It is known that the Maxwell equations in vacuum are  

$$
\nabla\cdot{\pmb{E}}=\frac{\rho}{\varepsilon_{0}}
$$

$$
\nabla\times{\pmb{{E}}}=-\frac{\partial{\pmb{{B}}}}{\partial t}
$$

$$
\nabla\cdot\pmb{B}=0

$$
\nabla\times\boldsymbol{B}=\mu_{0}\boldsymbol{j}+\varepsilon_{0}\mu_{0}\frac{\partial\boldsymbol{E}}{\partial t}
$$

To make the equations of electromagnetic fields more symmetrical, we introduce magnetic charge. Magnetic charge $\pmb{g}$ will generate a static magnetic field, and the motion of magnetic charge will generate a static electric field. It takes the following form:  

$$
\boldsymbol{B}={\frac{g \boldsymbol e_{r}}{4\pi r^{2}}}
$$

$$
\pmb{{E}}=\frac{\lambda g\pmb{{v}}\times\pmb{\boldsymbol{e}}_{r}}{4\pi c r^{2}}
$$

Find $\lambda$ by conservation of magnetic charge.
solutions:
$$
\pmb{\varepsilon}\rightarrow\pmb{\varepsilon}

It can be obtained:

$$
{\pmb B}\rightarrow\mu_{0}{\pmb B}c
$$

$$
\nabla\cdot\pmb{\cal E}=\rho

$$
\nabla\times\pmb{\mathcal{E}}=-\frac{1}{c}\frac{\partial\pmb{\mathcal{B}}}{\partial t}
$$
